docs.abstract: Renee Montgomery, a former Dream guard, is part of a group buying the W.N.B.A. team from Loeffler, the former Georgia senator who upset players by attacking the Black Lives Matter movement.
docs.snippet: Renee Montgomery, a former Dream guard, is part of a group buying the W.N.B.A. team from Loeffler, the former Georgia senator who upset players by attacking the Black Lives Matter movement.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Atlanta Dream, the W.N.B.A. team whose players revolted against a co-owner, Kelly Loeffler, and campaigned against her in a Georgia Senate race she lost, are being sold to an ownership group led by two real estate executives and a former star player for the team.

headline.main: Atlanta Dream Are Sold After Players’ Revolt Against Kelly Loeffler
headline.print_headline: Dream, Whose Players Campaigned Against Their Owner, Are Sold

byline.original: By Sopan Deb and Kevin Draper

docs.abstract: The newly opened Museum at The Times, on the 15th floor of the Times Building in New York, is filled with curios and artifacts that date back 170 years.
docs.snippet: The newly opened Museum at The Times, on the 15th floor of the Times Building in New York, is filled with curios and artifacts that date back 170 years.
docs.lead_paragraph: On the 15th floor of The New York Times Building, near a newspaper that traveled close to 1.8 million miles aboard the space shuttle Columbia, is a slab of metal shaped as the letter “S.” It is a piece from the “zipper,” a belt of 14,800 bulbs that The New York Times operated to send news bulletins around Times Square, beginning in 1928.

headline.main: High Above the Newsroom, a History of The Times

docs.abstract: They’re registering voters. They’re spotlighting the work of local organizers. They’re talking about all forms of gun violence.
docs.snippet: They’re registering voters. They’re spotlighting the work of local organizers. They’re talking about all forms of gun violence.
docs.lead_paragraph: Six months and a day after a gunman massacred 17 of their classmates and staff, the students of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School woke up Wednesday and began a new year.

headline.main: ‘Let Us Have a Childhood’: On the Road With the Parkland Activists

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School (Parkland, Fla)

byline.original: By Maggie Astor and Gabriella Angotti-Jones

docs.abstract: Three new story collections explore the vagaries of daily struggles.
docs.snippet: Three new story collections explore the vagaries of daily struggles.
docs.lead_paragraph: Leigh Newman finds in her native Alaska all that she needs to survey themes of betrayal and isolation, of desertion and disintegration (physical, psychological, spiritual). In her story collection NOBODY GETS OUT ALIVE (Scribner, 278 pp., $26), the heroic loom of the mountains — “contented giants, their faces slashed with ice and moonlight” — gives way to the splintered souls — “ailing, bewildered, clouded with regret” — who prowl the foothills below. A pair of sisters, crushed by their parents’ divorce and alcoholism, turn their pain on each other, riding a “diseased seesaw” of commitment and rejection. In “Slide and Glide,” a man attempts to save his marriage by compelling his family to undertake a risky wilderness trek, seeking “something more than love — trust.” And a California newcomer, convinced of the palliative “dazzle of Alaska,” discovers that “nothing here is fixed, nothing is any better. Where is there left to go, except out of your mind?”

headline.main: Stories of Survival, in the Wilds, in Cities and at Home

docs.abstract: With issues of race percolating in the N.F.L., several players reflect on Martin Luther King Jr. and his protest movement.
docs.snippet: With issues of race percolating in the N.F.L., several players reflect on Martin Luther King Jr. and his protest movement.
docs.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — It is doubtful that the N.F.L. owners understood, when they decided early in 2016 to play the Super Bowl here, how the city of Atlanta, as the cradle of the civil rights movement, would serve as a natural forum for the many complicated social and racial issues that have roiled the league in recent years.

headline.main: Atlanta Stokes a Civil Rights Conversation for Some Super Bowl Players
headline.print_headline: Patriots Become Pilgrims in Civil Rights Mecca

docs.abstract: The 1970 clip is a “miraculous” find, a former editor at the local CBS station said. It shows an interview with Prince, 11, commenting on a teachers’ strike in Minneapolis.
docs.snippet: The 1970 clip is a “miraculous” find, a former editor at the local CBS station said. It shows an interview with Prince, 11, commenting on a teachers’ strike in Minneapolis.
docs.lead_paragraph: Matthew Liddy, a production manager at WCCO-TV, a CBS station in Minnesota, was watching footage of a 1970 teachers’ strike in Minneapolis in late February when he saw a familiar face.

headline.main: Film at 11: How a Minnesota Station Found Old Footage of a Very Young Prince

docs.abstract: With boycotts and protests erupting at colleges across the country, politically active students find new debate partners: their parents.
docs.snippet: With boycotts and protests erupting at colleges across the country, politically active students find new debate partners: their parents.
docs.lead_paragraph: College in the summer: Dorms and quads are quiet, and it seems that the whole community is catching its breath. No marches, sit-ins, shout-downs, protesters giving professors whiplash. No arguments over free speech, Black Lives Matter, Israeli boycotts, abortion, Bernie Sanders, Hillary Clinton, President Trump.

headline.main: Campus Political Fights Come Home for the Summer
headline.print_headline: Coming Home, With Laundry  And Opinions

docs.abstract: Luke Mogelson watches the country go berserk in “The Storm Is Here.”
docs.snippet: Luke Mogelson watches the country go berserk in “The Storm Is Here.”
docs.lead_paragraph: Luke Mogelson is a journalist for The New Yorker who has reported from some of the world’s most harrowing and unlucky places, including Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria and Liberia. Before he returned to the United States in 2020 to cover our political convulsions, he hadn’t spent more than a few consecutive months in his native country in almost a decade.

headline.main: What This War Correspondent Wants You to Know About America and Fear

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: The Storm Is Here: An American Crucible (Book)

docs.abstract: A free math camp for middle-school students from New York’s poorest neighborhoods was an effort to increase the number of blacks and Latinos with advanced math degrees.
docs.snippet: A free math camp for middle-school students from New York’s poorest neighborhoods was an effort to increase the number of blacks and Latinos with advanced math degrees.
docs.lead_paragraph: One afternoon last summer at BEAM 6, an experimental program in downtown Manhattan for youths with a high aptitude for math, a swarm of 11- and 12-year-olds jockeyed for a better view of a poster labeled “Week One Challenge Problem.”

headline.main: Beyond ‘Hidden Figures’: Nurturing New Black and Latino Math Whizzes

docs.abstract: Security, the bedrock of the social order, has become deeply inequitable, fraying Mexican society and politics.
docs.snippet: Security, the bedrock of the social order, has become deeply inequitable, fraying Mexican society and politics.
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTERREY, Mexico — Viewed from above, greater Monterrey, with its corporate headquarters and golf resorts, appears as one city stretching between the mountains that surround it.

headline.main: ‘The Social Contract Is Broken’: Inequality Becomes Deadly in Mexico
headline.print_headline: Building Walls in a Violent Mexico as Inequality Rises

byline.original: By Max Fisher and Amanda Taub
